title: Before 1 August 2016, will any NATO members invoke Article 4 or Article 5 in response to actions taken by ISIS?
preds: According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Statistically calls for article 4 & 5 are rare but given the continued activities of ISIS again a variety of different countries there is a possibility that one of the NATO countries could invoke article 4 - but very unlikely in this time scaled
World jittery and volatile right now, feels like anything can happen any time now. For that reason, this is one question that needs to be monitored daily.
100% "no" now, primarily due to short time left.

Down 5% to be closer to consensus. Wonder if someone would trigger Article 4 (semi-related to something regarding Turkey). This would be a less confrontational way to chat about things without challenging Erdogan more directly.
I am forecasting based on the general news reports and GJP consensus.
Top bucket down 10% to be closer to consensus.  Wonder if Erdogan might find an ISIS link related to the coup attempt (even though most of his displeasure seems to be related to Gulen)?
Article 4 up 25% on Nice and NATO's desire to demonstrate a more robust anti-terrorist role. (not much time for this though)
I have been at 100% but after Nice I will come down again just in case.

Nobody cared about Turkey's recent Article 5 appeal against Syrian forces: https://www.carnegie.org/news/articles/turkeys-article-5-argument-finds-no-takers/ With this knowledge, I'd be surprised if they could get it against the Islamic State. Although it may just be pointless hedging, I am open to a slight possibility of the invocation of Article 4 only however.
I am forecasting based on the general news reports and GJP consensus.
Top bucket down 5%, mainly on passage of time.

Combed through the news around the NATO summit that just wrapped up. Unless a major event were to happen between now and August 1, is very unlikely that the present issues (ISIS attacks in Turkey, France) would trigger it.
Top bucket down 5% since it didn't happen at the NATO summit.
Changed my mind based on @cdob63 post http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/276625 There is a VERY slim difference between Erdogan encouraging (or whatever the english word was) NATO and Article 4.

http://www.reuters.com/article/us-nato-summit-erdogan-idUSKCN0ZO0KR?il=0
This is almost enough to make me move my numbers, except I think he mostly wants help killing his fellow Turkish folks--Kurds, political opponents, journalists, comedians, people of that ilk.   May not be much support for that.
Last 5% to "no" chiefly on the question closing soon.
Top bucket down 5% on passage of time.
Top bucket down 5% for passage of time.

http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-idUSKCN0ZG2V3 Today's complication for your life, or at least for mine:  Hair Boy suggests mobilizing NATO "in response to actions taken by ISIS."  If somebody asks for an Article 4 meeting to talk about possible NATO reactions to Trump's remarks, would that count as a Yes for this Q?  Such a meeting would not exactly be about a response to ISIS, but a response to the remarks of a private US  citizen.  Of course a very low-probability event, but this has so far been a good year for drawing to an inside straight.  I'm still guessing it wouldn't count--just looking for something else to fret over.
If additional ISIS attacks in NATO countries continues eventually article 4 & possibly with article 5 may be invoked.
Updated to reflect Istanbul airport attacks.

There is not point but to rally support to the coalition
Moving to 99% from 97% due to time factor.
(no change) After Euro 2016 I'll probably adjust the top bucket down some.
Article 4 has been invoked 4 times since 2003. 2% chance seems a reasonable estimate given that frequency and the time frame.

During an interview on C-SPAN's "Communicators," Hurd said the lack of a definition emboldens U.S. adversaries to act without fear of retribution, like in the case of the apparent Russian hack of the Democratic National Committee. 
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  I gather that since we don't have a definition of digital act of war, no-one is likely to be accused of it.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

(no change) Wonder how quickly some information from Egypt Air's downed aircraft black boxes will leak out?
Going with the flow I guess
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Talked myself into going up 5% on first bucket.  http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/254883 Could be a complicated summer and NATO might want to hedge its bets in case DT becomes POTUS. If a new mission, then perhaps less irrelevant.

(no change and no link) DT is claiming NATO is more serious now about terrorism because of his prodding. Silly of course, OTOH if NATO is carving out something related to terrorism, demonstrating how it contributes isn't much of a stretch.
If I could go decimal on yes to 4&5, I would.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

(no change) Would Erdogan want a discussion within NATO regarding Germany recognizing the Armenian genocide? Perhaps 30%. If broached, could that be wrapped into a more general discussion of terrorism and ISIS sufficient to close this as a yes? Probably a real stretch of ~5%.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Must update as very little activity of US in the last few months. Must also focus on internal issues, I suppose.
Zeroing top bucket since no initiatives from France.
Back down top bucket 10% since France hasn't asked for a discussion within NATO.

Pressure is on and ISIS will be kept busy in Syria and Iraq for the foreseeable future, but that doesn't mean they won't seek opportunities to lash out in Europe and/or North America within the next couple months. It'll have to be a significant and successful attack for a member to invoke Article 4 or Article 5 though.

(no change) Finding the black boxes from the Egypt Air flight may take a very long time. Absent data which may be released to the press publicly, would France take the general issue of aircraft vulnerability to NATO for discussion to show some effort at dealing with the problems?
Up 20% top bucket on chance France might like to talk after the Egypt Air incident.

Let's lower the numbers. Nothing so serious has been down. Even if the 'disappearance' of the Egyptian plane is due to an ISIS strike (doubtful), then I still don't think it will happen. (4) 8% --> 4%
(NO) 89% --> 93% I still believe that if a member wants to invoke article 5 it will first invoke 4, so I give "BOTH" a higher percentage than (5), which I leave unchanged.

Although Trump's rhetoric on NATO not being designed to fight terrorism may eventually trigger some compensatory action from NATO, the timeline has less than 3 months to play out. That is much shorter than than the Russia question which has the full year to play out. So, I have decided to lower my 8% to 5% to be basically at par with the crowd on this one. Only disagreement left over is that I don't see Article 5 being invoked.
More ISIS trouble coming to Europe. Countries with joint borders will start consulting. France and Belgium, Germany and Italy are possible participants.
Modifying due to passage of time
Top bucket down 5% (actually more like 2% but going to zero to compensate for higher forecasts). Perhaps NATO has telegraphed that they are relevant enough without getting sucked into the swamp.

I think any further action is highly unlikely, especially till August 1. However, the article 4 is not something so hard to invoke, but article 5 is. Invoking 5 without invoking 4 seems impossible to me, especially about ISIS. I do leave a 1% and 2% possibilities for those, but it is only because we don't know what ISIS and Turkey might do next. Especially ISIS is hard to predict... Anyway, these are baseline predictions, and the consesus view also weighed heavily on me.
Decreasing top bucket 5% to be closer to consensus.
I don't believe ISIS cares what NATO does.  Invoking Articles 4 or 5 would be pointless.

Will prefer to be marginally above consensus on this question, as long as Trump remains a factor in the Presidential elections. NATO might want to show it is active and relevant to the terrorism problem, by doing Article 4. Article 5 is unlikely to happen.
If it was gonna happen, you'd think it would have been done after the Belgium attacks.
If NATO declares Article 4, does it mean they've technically recognized the Caliphate?
What we saw in Brussels is the new normal.
Down 5% and 10% on top two buckets. The purported cells already in place are worrying.

My forecast is very high for "no".  Since Brussels, I'm wondering if I'm too high.  If Belgium experiences a couple more terrorist attacks in the next few months, might they not invoke one of these articles?

Reducing evocation probabilities across the board, due to the relaxation in the region. Russia pulled back from Syria, Ukraine moved out of the news, the north-eastern NATO countries seem to be more confident and Turkey is on the way to a civil war were NATO will stay out of.
Therefore it seems unlikely for Putin to steer up enough problems to make a border country invoke Art4/5 and Turkey would make a very strong argument that an attack didn't come from Kurdisch people but from ISIS, to have a chance of having the claim accepted.

Article 5 Has only been invoked once, and in an extremely large scale attack (9/11). Even though Article 4 is more common due to less extreme, it's still not invoked that often.
After the Paris attacks, it was possible the for Articles to be invoked, yet were not.

Other than 9/11 no country has issued article 5 against a terrorist group. This is because article 5 is directed towards a state, when terrorist groups aren’t states. But since the increasing attacks IS has been committing, and the outcry for them to be gone, it is somewhat possible a nation would issue article 5.
ISIS is being defeated in both Syria and Iraq. The need for NATO action doesn't exist.

Increased terrorism, which is identified as originating from and claimed by ISIS, could very well be grounds to bring the issue to the UN Security Council which could provide NATO with authority to increase military operations against ISIS to curtail such terrorism. I do not see that ISIS poses a direct threat to NATO states, or that a state such as Turkey considers itself threatened or will consider it necessary to act against ISIS.
Up 10% (4) and 5% (5) on Brussels, et al.
Increasing Article 4 and Articles 4 & 5 to 15%, in light of today's attack in Brussels and the threat of more to come.
Only Turkey is in sufficient proximity with ISIS to take Article 4 or 5 route, but Turkey wants ISIS to do its thing!

I originally assigned 7%, 2%, 1%, and 90% to this problem on January 21st. Since 25% of the time has passed since then, I am updating my forecasts downward by 25%, then rounding them, to account for the passage of time.

I don't see NATO invoking Article 5 against a terrorist group. 9/11 was a outlying circumstance since: a) America had been attacked and it became clear that other NATO countries were likely targets and that it would only be a matter of time before one suffered an attack 2.) Afghanistan was effectively a sovereign nation under Taliban rule, which provided NATO forces an easy target to invade in order to pursue al Qaeda (whose central leadership was using Afghanistan as a base of operations).  Syria/Iraq is too chaotic and with Russia operating there (amid speculation of a possible ground campaign by a Saudi-led Sunni coalition) a NATO intervention would risk a wider conflict with Russia. Besides, no NATO member wants to get involved in nation-building after 10+ years of doing so in Afghanistan.

Dateline 2-19-16 Turkish military hit PYD/YPG targets in Syria on Thursday night with artillery rockets positioned in southern Hatay province.
According to reports, the rockets targeting PYD/YPG positions in Syria's Afrin were launched late Thursday and continued to hit the targets on Friday morning.
Turkey pounded PYD/YPG targets near Syria's Azaz on Thursday with T-155 Fırtına howitzers, in retaliation for the terrorist organization's cross-border fire into southern border town Kilis.
Previously, the military shelled YPG targets near the town of Azaz in northern Syria on Feb. 13, under the rules of engagement and in response to two separate attacks carried out by YPG and Assad forces on a Turkish military base and a police station. http://www.dailysabah.com/politics/2016/02/19/turkey-hits-ypgpyd-targets-with-artillery-rockets

I'm raising Article 4 20% on news NATO is trying to help stem flow of sea borne migrants from Turkey. Guessing that if NATO has any role, it is an easy step to regularize it and show that NATO can have a role related to ISIS.

Action would require a significant event. Determining the threshold is difficult, tolerance for violence and casualties has grown. It would most likely take something more than Madrid or London and perhaps not quite as bad as 9-11 to create calls for Article 4.

The historical use of Art. 4 is much more likely. While an attack or continued conflict between Russian and Turkish forces in the future, based on the parties positioning and potential economic conflict seems more likely than not, the loss of position for ISIS at the edges of the battlefield would indicate that as a ground force, they will continue to degrade as a fighting force on the battlefield. I expect that ISIS inspired events will continue, but like AQ, this movement will be forced into a decentralized battle as the head(s) of the movement are killed or captured. Additionally, the Kurdish forces will provide a buffer against IS incursions into Turkey. Turkey is far more concerned with controlling the Kurds, and maintaining internal stability, and IS will keep Kurdish paramilitary forces facing away from Turkey for the next 12 months. Thus, IS's presence will hold Kurdish forces in place, and will decrease the likelihood of Turkey calling for forces or assistance in the battle against IS.

The fact that  the border is still open is still an indication that the war on Kurds everywhere and all the time  is E focus. That and getting rid of Assad. ISIS threat receding except for random acts of terror in Istanbul.

There's only been one time in history when article 5 was ever invoked: following the 9/11 attacks in 2001.  Turkey came close in 2012 (for Syria). Article 5 seems to be a really big deal and won't be invoked lightly. Also note that there is already a NATO-based coalition attacking ISIS already.   Likewise, Article 4 are also rare; it has been invoked 4 times by Turkey (which seems the most likely country to invoke it on ISIS/ISIL), including once against ISIS in 2015. However, Turkey seems very unlikely to invoke it again on ISIS, and none of the other NATO members seem likely to invoke it. So I think it's maybe 10%  that either of them are invoked, distributed as 7%, 2%, 1%. (Article 4 and 5 both being invoked seems extremely implausible.)
Turkey if they are attacked at the Syrian border.

There doesn't appear to be anything to discuss in an Article 4, and military intervention seems to be going on country by country, rather than through NATO.  No reason to expect this to change, as far as I can tell. One hopes this explanation sounds tentative enough.

Isis is not a country or nation.  There is no place to direct the consultation about.  This problem is going to have to fizzle out after they are seen for the wakos they are.  It will go the way of the IRA and the KKK.  It will take decades but the demons lose in the end.  Just like in the movies the good guys win in the end.
Returning to previous probability forecast level.

Article 5 has been invoked just once, thus the likelihood is small that it will be invoked again by August. Article 4 has been invoked just 5 times (for any reason), all of them since 2003. Aside from Poland's use of Article 4 in 2014, Turkey is the only other country to have invoked it. Since Turkey has already invoked Article 4 with respect to Syria and ISIS, it's unlikely they'll do so again by August.

Article 4 talks about action when any member sees a threat to security,  which seems much more likely to be claimed. This is a confusing question. The last answer is "No" where typically all questions are "yes".

Reducing prob. The more I think about this, the less likely it seems. We're all aware of ISIS, and there are plenty of airstrikes already underway by NATO members. I just can't understand what invocation of either of these sections of the charter would accomplish. Here are the circumstance that I think could result in a yes vote on either: Article 4: Major strike by ISIS, bigger than the Paris attacks. Very unlikely; 5% is probably generous. Article 5: ISIS makes a sustained assault on the territorial integrity of a NATO member (Turkey). I believe this is flatly beyond their capabilities, but I'll throw in 2% for "anything can happen."

Although Turkey request Article 4 quite a bit, I don't see it necessary for any country to seek special counsel under Article 4 at this point in time. The NATO allies are working together on the same page.  I do see Article 4 being invoked if, or when, Russia finally retaliates against Turkey for the downed fighter jet, but this is about ISIS.  Article 5 is redundant since the NATO forces are already acting against ISIL as though it was an Article 5 invocation.  I'm leaving 10% for some strange situation that I haven't considered.
Minor adjustments. Not 4 & 5 at the same time. Still think NATO management may wish for a more prominent role. Either 4 or 5 might not fit the typical crisis planning assumptions.

It is already given that ISIS has attacked multiple countries through its cells. The attack on ISIS is more or less unified already. There will not be a further need to invoke Article 5. Article 4 is operative in which a member country discusses a threat to territorial integrity, political independence or security, [but it would be purely for information] or consultation.  If the conflict between Turkey and Russia escalates, depending on the particular typography of conflict, then Article 4 is likely to be invoked.  However, given Russia's response to the downing if it's plane over (Syria or Turkey) depending on whose perspective is most likely plausible, verifiable based on current evidence provided to NATO.  Article 5, used only once (immediately invoked after 9/11), NATO members appear to have greater caution in the use of Article 5, invoking the collective defense clause of the NATo Treaty. A visibly angry Russian President Vladimir Putin, meeting with Jordan’s King Abdullah in Sochi, lashed out at Turkey, calling the downing of the plane a “stab in our back delivered by accomplices of the terrorists.” Putin also said he found it suspicious that Turkey had called for an emergency meeting of NATO after the incident, as if a Turkish plane had been downed instead of one of Russia’s. NATO was due to hold an emergency meeting at 11 a.m. EST Nov. 24.
Russia’s Ministry of Defense claimed the downed Sukhoi had not entered Turkish territory. Meanwhile, Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov, scheduled to travel to Turkey Nov. 25, canceled his trip and urged Russians not to travel to Turkey for the time being, according to reports citing the Foreign Ministry.

In response to a question I was asked in a discussion this morning about Turkey having shot down a Russian Flanker - I said this -
It captures ones imagination. I have long had reason believe that the Turkish F-4 shoot down at the start of the Syrian Spring was the result of a Russian Tech standing at the console direction the air battle.  If so this could be a simple tit for tat. The Flanker (which is a Russian version of the Tomcat) flight profile is typical of that used in Chechen ground attacks. It may be that it was attacking Turk supported rebels. This would be a message that continuing to support  anti-Assad forces from inside Turkey and attacks launched from there - will no longer be tolerated by Russia. Erdogan could use this as another element of his case for a safe zone/No-Fly zone. (it would also be cause to invoke Article 5 NATO). Will the Pentagon or French analysis side with him? Will a unilateral statement to the effect that the Radar track verify's Turkeys contention that it was in there airspace? Coupled with Turkeys recent cancellation of a contract for a Chinese missile system, it could be that Turkey is back in the NATO fold again, and that its adventures with foreign powers is over. How long before Lavrov insists that it was just a right of navigation flight? The Russian response may tell us a lot.  Lets not forget either that this has been a boost to Oil Prices which aids Russia immeasurably. I'm trying to find out if any NATO / American bases went on alert as well, or merely cancelled 1/2 day schedules and/or cancelled leave for any particular force - especially air-defense battery types. What do you think of it? Is it even conceivable that the pilot was just being reckless?

"When President Hollande declared a state of war with ISIS, he deliberately chose to invoke Article 42.7 of the Lisbon Treaty, not Article V of the NATO treaty.  Article 42.7 is the “solidarity clause” that states if a member of the European Union is the victim of “armed aggression on its territory,” other EU member states have an “obligation of aid and assistance by all the means in their power.”  In essence, France chose to work within a European framework, without formally drawing in NATO and the U.S. direction that would entail. [1] [1] http://breakingdefense.com/2015/11/arab-spring-to-paris-fall-a-strategic-shift-in-the-works

Article 4 is essentially a capability to force a consultation among members for a specific topic/concern. Fairly innocuous, so likely to be invoked. Article 5 is essentially the capability to invoke a mutual protection requirement on all members based on a single member's fear of being attacked ( or, having been attacked). This is a big deal, and only invoked once. Three weeks ago, little chance of Article 5 invocation. Now, everything is different. With ISIS pledging more attacks......even Anonymous hacker group is warning of many pending possible attacks...and Leon Panetta publicly embracing Article 5. The landscape has dramatically shifted.

That's a hard one:
I expect Stoltenberg is lobbying for consultation right now! NATO wants to be the primary security alliance, but currently has the problem, that for 20 years NATO has not delivered much because of many factors:
Military budget cuts, lack of European capabilities, lack of clear enemy, Afghanistan-conflict not popular and in public opinion more of an US-led operation than NATO.
Moreover NATO's capabilities are 80% US capabilities and the US tend to "their" affairs themselves.
Also, NATO has not yet found the means to counter terrorist/unconventional threats (including media/propaganda), so those matters are not considered military but rather police/intelligence-service matters.
Because of that, many nations have established other "security-related-channels, mostly bilateral ones (good thing for Putin, btw.). Because of all this NATO's "street-cred" has gone down quite a lot, so NATO could benefit if someone invoked Article 4 (let alone 5) and become more relevant again - which would be a threat for Russia!
The Ukraine-conflict seemed to change all that - for a while, with a sharp increase in NATO's relevancy in today's world.
Now, NATO as an organization is much more relevant to the small eastern European powers, because they still face the traditional threat of bordering Russia and for a short time only, their pleas were heard internationally.
If for only one minute, it would be generally accepted that NATO member states would NOT react forcefully, all-out(!!!), when Russian troops cross the border of a NATO member-state (let's say a baltic state, because of civil unrest or because terrorists are believed to hide there or there was an attack on a Russian radio-station just across the border;-)), NATO would be DEAD. Therefore I suspect, that Putin sending troops to Syria serves one main purpose: Open up a new front, distract from the Ukraine-conflict and thereby undermine NATO further. Putin has succeeded with exactly that: Because Europe themselves are not able to carry out any meaningful action in Syria and the middle east, they HAVE to live with Russia being an ally for the time being. However Because of this alliance (or tacit acceptance of the situation, if you will), western Europan countries will carry out NO actions whatsoever in and around Syria with NATO forces or NATO-lead, hell, even involving NATO-HQs. Moreover I am convinced they will block any such endeavors (that is: involve NATO) by the US or eastern-European states. To come back to the point at hand: NATO Consultation in general is rare and in this context even more so, because firstly many nations believe NATO to not be relevant to new security challenges and secondly it has to potential to put the western-European allies to shame (lack of military capabilities, need to align to Putin's policy) and because of the situation of Russian troops in Syria. So there is only one way that I expect consultation might happen: An eastern-European power might call for consultations to bring the anti-terror-fight to NATO as a sort of a wildcard move because they understand what Putin is up for. Therefore I my estimate is:

No: 70%

Article 4 is not as big of a deal, but has already been invoked by NATO countries in response to ISIS and Putin; it's basically a way of elevating a problem to a greater level of importance for the rest of NATO. Considering that Article 4 has already been invoked for both of the above troublemakers, I don't see much point in doing it again. P(4)=10% 4. The probability of two independent events P(4) and and P(5) both occurring is P(4)*P(5), which gets us to 0.5%. In reality P(4) and P(5) are not independent, and each makes the other less likely. So P(4&5) is significantly less than 1%, which will get rounded down to 0%. 5. P(No)=whatever is left, or 85%.
WIth ISIS on the rampage I don't think anybody needs to invoke an Article to get a conversation going.
